item.title: vim: save with sudo
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded: .vimrc:cmap w!! %!sudo tee > /dev/null %
item.excerpt:encoded: .vimrc: cmap w!! %!sudo tee > /dev/null %

item.title: basename and dirname using build in shell stuff
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
file="/usr/local/bin/testfile"
basename="${file##*/}"
dirname="${file%/*}"
item.excerpt:encoded: file="/usr/local/bin/testfile" basename="${file##*/}" dirname="${file%/*}"

item.title: git. filter repository and left only some folders.
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
This command give you a clue on how to seperate one repository into several

git filter-branch --prune-empty --subdirectory-filter folder-that-will-stay -- --all
item.excerpt:encoded: This command give you a clue on how to seperate one repository into several git filter-branch --prune-empty --subdirectory-filter folder-that-will-stay -- --all

item.title: postfix+gmail relay
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
Install the required packages

sudo aptitude install postfix libsasl2 ca-certificate libsasl2-modules

Configure Postfix

/etc/postfix/main.cf:

relayhost = [smtp.gmail.com]:587
smtp_sasl_auth_enable = yes
smtp_sasl_password_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/sasl_passwd
smtp_sasl_security_options = noanonymous
smtp_tls_CAfile = /etc/postfix/cacert.pem
smtp_use_tls = yes

Define Username and Password

/etc/postfix/sasl_passwd:

[smtp.gmail.com]:587    user.name@gmail.com:password

sudo chmod 400 /etc/postfix/sasl_passwd
sudo postmap /etc/postfix/sasl_passwd

At this point you can restart Postfix and it should work, however it will complain about not being able to authenticate the certificate.  To take care of this issue we’ll use the ca-certificate package we installed and tell it where it can validate the certificate.

cat /etc/ssl/certs/Thawte_Premium_Server_CA.pem | sudo tee -a /etc/postfix/cacert.pem
item.excerpt:encoded: Install the required packages sudo aptitude install postfix libsasl2 ca-certificate libsasl2-modules Configure Postfix /etc/postfix/main.cf: relayhost = [smtp.gmail.com]:587smtp_sasl_auth_enable = yessmtp_sasl_password_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/sas...

item.title: python2 and unicode
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
Set system encoding:

export LANG=en_US.UTF-8

export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8

Decode to ASAP 

def to_unicode_or_bust(obj, encoding='utf-8'):   if isinstance(obj, basestring)      if not isinstance(obj, unicode):         obj = unicode(obj, encoding)   return obj

Shortcuts


codecs.open()
import codecs
f = codecs.open('/tmp/ivan_utf8.txt', 'w', encoding='utf-8' )
f.read()
f.write(ivan_uni)
f.close()

Based on this slideshow http://farmdev.com/talks/unicode/
item.excerpt:encoded: Set system encoding: export LANG=en_US.UTF-8 export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 Decode to ASAP def to_unicode_or_bust(obj, encoding='utf-8'): if isinstance(obj, basestring) if not isinstance(obj, unicode): obj = unicode(obj, encoding) return obj Shortcuts ...

item.title: Bacula. How to remove purged volumes from the disk.
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
List of volumes which is not in use:

sqlite3 /var/spool/bacula/bacula.db "select VolumeName from Media where VolStatus != 'Used'"


How to remove bacula Volumes which are not in use:

sqlite3 /var/spool/bacula/bacula.db "select VolumeName from Media where VolStatus != 'Used'" | xargs -INAME rm -v /ebs/bacula/storage/NAME
item.excerpt:encoded: List of volumes which is not in use: sqlite3 /var/spool/bacula/bacula.db "select VolumeName from Media where VolStatus != 'Used'" How to remove bacula Volumes which are not in use: sqlite3 /var/spool/bacula/bacula.db "select VolumeName from Media ...

item.title: OpenWRT Kamikaze. howto allow VPN from internal net
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
Here is simple and working solution for Openwrt kamikaze linux to allow VPN (pptp,gre) connections from internal lan. Also you can use it for allowing SIP calls from your internal lan and use SNMP tools.
No need any changes in /etc/firewall.user or /etc/config/firewall files.

Just connect to your router using SSH protocol. After connection established, type this commands:
ipkg upgrade
ipkg install kmod-ipt-nathelper-extra
reboot

All should works after system loads!

Package kmod-ipt-nathelper-extra install this kernel modules into your system:

- ip_conntrack_amanda
- ip_conntrack_proto_gre
- ip_nat_proto_gre
- ip_conntrack_pptp
- ip_nat_pptp
- ip_conntrack_sip
- ip_nat_sip
- ip_nat_snmp_basic

The moust interesting for us is ip_nat_proto_gre, which loads support of GRE packets into linux kernel and pass it to your local workstation. Now you can connect from you internal net, using Windows/OSX/Linux/"put your OS here".

If you need only VPN ...

... and no need SIP, TFTP, H323, IRC, SNMP, than remove this files /etc/modules.d/40-ipt-extra, /etc/modules.d/40-ipt-nathelper:rm /etc/modules.d/40-ipt-extrarm /etc/modules.d/40-ipt-nathelperand leave in file /etc/modules.d/40-ipt-nathelper-extra only this lines: ip_conntrack_proto_gre ip_nat_proto_gre ip_conntrack_pptp ip_nat_pptp

On my Kamikaze this works fine. Good luck!
item.excerpt:encoded: Here is simple and working solution for Openwrt kamikaze linux to allow VPN (pptp,gre) connections from internal lan. Also you can use it for allowing SIP calls from your internal lan and use SNMP tools. No need any changes in /etc/firewall.user o...

item.title: Caffeinism
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
The Addictive Properties of Caffeine

If you have difficulty relating to people or dealing with life before you have had your morning cup of coffee, you may well be addicted to caffeine-the condition now referred to as "caffeinism". Caffeine is an addictive substance that produces a well-defined abstinence syndrome when abruptly discontinued: headache, irritability, lethargy, drowsiness, fatigue, depression and even nausea in some people.

Recent research shows that even people who consume relatively small amounts of caffeine (e.g., two cups of coffee daily) may experience such severe withdrawal symptoms that they quickly return to their brew. Indeed, relapse is a hallmark of addiction; it refers to the tendency to return to the drug after a period of abstinence. This is certainly a common experience with people who attempt to withdraw from caffeine-which begs the question: is it even necessary to give up caffeine? As with many issues, the answer is: "it depends".

So What If I Use Caffeine?

The use of caffeinated beverages is simply a part of society. While studies show that caffeine adds a subjective flavor value to beverages, the fact of the matter is that taste is only part of the reason people use caffeine. Most people who use caffeine regularly will admit that its mild stimulant properties are a boon to their energy level, mood and productivity. So what's wrong with that? Probably nothing, provided your caffeine use causes no problems for you.

People vary in their sensitivity to the acute effects of caffeine. Some people experience the characteristic signs of over-stimulation with minimal doses: jitteriness, nervousness, sleeplessness, heart palpitations and irritability. Others can consume copious amounts of caffeine with seemingly no negative effects whatsoever. Other potential problems from caffeine include muscle tension, headaches, ringing in the ears (tinnitus) and stomach irritation.

Caffeine is a diuretic-a drug that increases the output of urine-so using caffeinated beverages as the only source of fluid could lead to dehydration. A sign of early dehydration is a sensation of warmth, often in the hands and feet, that is not explained by room temperature or excess clothing. (Drinking water will relieve this in short order.)

If you experience no negative effects from your caffeine use, it may not be necessary to cut down or eliminate it from your diet at all. Perhaps the issue in deciding this question should be whether your caffeine use causes any long- term effects-and that probably depends on how much and how often you use it.

Long-Term Effects of Caffeine

Most of the "caffeine research" is actually coffee research. And since coffee contains numerous substances besides caffeine, it is uncertain whether the results of coffee research can be attributed solely to caffeine. Nevertheless, the literature tends to apply conclusions about coffee research to caffeine use in general.

In the last decade, many articles have claimed that there is a link between coffee and a variety of cancers-bladder, pancreas, colon, ovary and kidney to name a few. But evaluation of 16,000 men and women observed from 1967 to 1979 found no correlation between coffee consumption and cancer at any body site. In fact, some studies have actually suggested that caffeine may protect against some cancers.

Although most obstetricians advise their pregnant patients to abstain from caffeine or limit consumption to less than 200 mg. per day, there is no evidence linking birth defects with caffeine, nor is it known to cause hyperactivity in children. The greatest harm to coffee's reputation in recent years has come from research on heart disease. Several studies have shown that daily consumption of three to five cups of coffee significantly increases blood cholesterol levels (high blood cholesterol is a major risk factor for coronary artery disease).

Moreover, a Norwegian study of 14,500 men and women showed that heavy coffee drinkers with high blood cholesterol who abstained from coffee lowered their cholesterol levels an average of 13 percent. But further analysis of the data showed that the coffee drinkers tended to smoke, consume more fats and lead sedentary lives- all significant contributors to high blood cholesterol, therefore, the conclusions are believed to be invalid.

Experts do not question that caffeine can increase heart rate, blood pressure and cause irregular heart beat. However, these effects are minimal and are of no consequence in people who have no symptoms of heart or artery disease.

Much has been written in popular and professional literature about caffeine and breast disorders in women. Caffeine is not suspected of causing breast cancer, but it clearly causes breast swelling and associated tenderness. If this is a problem for you, cutting down or eliminating caffeine may be the best choice. There appears to be no justification for the claim that caffeine causes fibrocystic breast condition (benign cysts in the breasts that may be tender).

Caffeine stimulates the production of stomach acids and thus should not be used by people who have ulcers and limited by people who are prone to stomach irritation. In fact, heavy consumption of caffeinated beverages may actually cause ulcers. Caffeine use may be something you want to monitor if you are trying to lose weight, since it causes release of fats into the blood stream, which set up an insulin reaction that can result in low blood sugar. The primary implication of this is that low blood sugar is a signal to eat.

If you find that caffeine use is associated with a need to eat unscheduled meals during a weight-loss program, then evaluate whether eliminating it is something you want to do. The basic answer to the question, "is caffeine bad for me?" is that it's okay for healthy people in moderation. Moderation is always tricky to define, but studies on the ill effects of caffeine found that 200-300 mg daily produces no negative long-term effects. (See the equivalency chart to find out how much caffeine your beverage has relative to that.)

In the final analysis, your use of caffeine is a personal choice and its risk to your health should be considered in light of all other health risks you experience. And like all other choices you make about your health, it's good to have some facts on which to base decisions.

Caffeine Source

Caffeine is found not only in coffee, tea, chocolate and colas, but also in other soft drinks such as Mountain Dew " and in some over-the-counter (OTC) drugs such as Anacin". Generally speaking, coffee contains more caffeine than tea, but that may depend on how long the tea was steeped; green teas have less caffeine than black teas. The chart on the next page provides a comparison of the caffeine content of various products.

Caffeine Content

Beverages

 

BevergeBeverage AmountCaffeine Amount (mg)
Coffee (drip)5 oz.110 - 150
Coffee (perk)5 oz.60 - 125
Coffee (instant)5 oz.40 - 105
Coffee (decaf)5 oz.2 - 5
Tea (5 min. deep)5 oz.40 -100
Tea (3 min. deep)5 oz.20 - 50
Hot cocoa5 oz.2 - 10
Cola (diet/regular)12 oz.36 - 49
Dr. Pepper/Mr. Pibb12 oz.40
Orange soda12 oz.40
Mountain Dew12 oz.40

Non-caffeinated drinks include: 7-Up, Fresca, Fanta products, Squirt, Teem, Canada Dry Ginger Ale and Hires Root Beer

Food

 

FoodsFood AmountCaffeine Amount (mg)
Milk chocolate1 oz.1 - 15
Bittersweet chocolate1 oz.5 - 35
Chocolate cake1 average slice20 - 30

Over-the-Counter Drugs

 

MedicationDosageCaffeine Amount (mg)
Anacin2 tablets64
Empirin2 tablets64
Midol2 tablets64
Excedrin2 tablets130
NoDoz2 tablets200
Aqua-Ban (diuretic)2 tablets200
Dexatrim1 capsule200

Cutting Down Or Eliminating Caffeine

If you choose to cut down or eliminate caffeine, do it gradually over a period of about a week. You can do it by:

  • reducing the number of uses each day
  • decreasing the amount in each use
  • decreasing the caffeine content of each use. For example, if you get your cola from a dispenser, fill your cup half with decaffeinated and half with regular. You may discover after cutting down that your negative effects remit, making eliminating caffeine unnecessary.

On the other hand, a "hardcore" caffeine addict may not be able to cut down permanently; they often gradually work their way back to the prior level of use. If this happens to you, it may be time to make another decision: whether to cut caffeine out altogether. Again, the ultimate choice will depend on what kind, if any, problems you experience from caffeine.

What About Decaffeinated Coffee?

Perhaps you heard that decaffeinated coffee is no better for you than the "real" thing. That really depends on whether the "real thing" causes you problems in the first place. If stomach problems caused you to give up your preferred brew, decaf will not treat you any better. The acid and other chemicals in decaf create the same gastric environment as regular coffee.

One worry about decaffeinated coffee has been put to rest, however. It was once thought to be carcinogenic because of the solvent (methylene chloride) used to extract caffeine from some brands. This chemical was shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals when inhaled, but not when consumed.

Moreover, the amount of solvent remaining in the bean after decaffeination is so minimal as to be of little concern. But there are plenty of water-processed decaffeinated coffees available if this issue is of concern to you, although the extra expense of them probably offers no appreciable health advantages.

A Stanford University study that showed decaffeinated coffee to raise LDL ("bad") cholesterol in the blood was found to be flawed. The increase in the 181 volunteers (a small sample of just men) was only 5 mg per deciliter of blood-a statistically insignificant increase. Moreover, the coffees used by each group (caf and decaf) were made from different beans, which could have accounted for this minute difference.

Consider the known facts relative to caffeine and make good choices for yourself.

item.title: python: shove
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded: # Store persistent objects in filesfile_data = Shove('file://path/to/file')# Store persistent objects in a BSDDB database file bsdb_data = Shove('bsddb://path/to/file')  # Store persistent objects in SVN svn_data = Shove('svn://user:password@http://svn.mydomain.com/path/to/svn') # Store persistent objects in S3s3_data = Shove('s3://s3_key:s3_secret@bucket') # Store persistent objects in SQLite using SQLAlchemysqlite_data = Shove('sqlite:///relative/path/to/database.txt')  #To compress data that you store, pass compress=True as an argument # Store compressed data in the 'data.db' BSDDB file bsddb_data = Shove('bsddb://data.db', compress=True)

item.title: Rules of thumb for geocoordinates
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
I'm doing some geographic hacking. I get confused about degrees, seconds, fractions, and precision of coordinates. Here's some approximations for how far distances are for latitude degrees. Imperial measures, my apologies to my non-American friends who are not crippled by years of non-metric education.
1 degree    70 miles    1 minute    1.15 miles    1 second     100 feet    0.1 degree   7 miles    0.01 degree 3600 feet    0.001 degree    360 feet    0.0001 degree   36 feet    0.00001 degree   4 feet
Those numbers are for latitude. Longitudes get narrower at the poles. At San Francisco's latitude of 37 degrees, a degree of longitude is about 55 miles, or about 80% of a degree of latitude.

via somebits.com
item.excerpt:encoded: I'm doing some geographic hacking. I get confused about degrees, seconds, fractions, and precision of coordinates. Here's some approximations for how far distances are for latitude degrees. Imperial measures, my apologies to my non-American friend...

item.title: Mysql-Cluster ndbd monitoring with nagios
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
During usage of ndbd nodes (table type ndbcluster), a lot of strange things happens :-)
One and the most terrible is ndbd daemon termination without any warring messages in logs or core files. This plugin helps inform Nagios if ndbd doing something wrong check_ndbd

Brief howto

Every service on mysqld-cluster have own ID. This id you can get from ndb_mgm output:

~% ndb_mgm -c host=ndbhost-- NDB Cluster -- Management Client --ndb_mgm> showConnected to Management Server at: db04:1186Cluster Configuration---------------------[ndbd(NDB)]     2 node(s)id=3    @10.10.10.204  (Version: 5.0.32, Nodegroup: 0)id=4    @10.10.10.205  (Version: 5.0.32, Nodegroup: 0, Master)[ndb_mgmd(MGM)] 2 node(s)id=1    @10.10.10.204  (Version: 5.0.32)id=2    @10.10.10.205  (Version: 5.0.32)[mysqld(API)]   2 node(s)id=5    @10.10.10.204  (Version: 5.0.32)id=6    @10.10.10.205  (Version: 5.0.32)ndb_mgm>

Find your NDB node ID. For me ID is 3 and 4.
Than use Nagios script:
check_ndbd ndbdhost 3

Here is Nagios checkcommand part:

define command{        command_name    check_ndbd        command_line    /opt/sbin/check_ndbd $HOSTADDRESS$ $ARG1$}

 

Here is Nagios service part:

define service{        use clusterservice        hostgroup_name        mysql-cluster        service_description    mysql ndbd node 3        check_command          check_ndbd!3}
item.excerpt:encoded: During usage of ndbd nodes (table type ndbcluster), a lot of strange things happens :-) One and the most terrible is ndbd daemon termination without any warring messages in logs or core files. This plugin helps inform Nagios if ndbd doing somethin...

item.title: Red Hat GFS monitoring
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
During usage of GFS some of nodes getting I/O errors on GFS filesystem. A little script helps be informed about nodes with such problems check_gfs

Check of GFS from command line example:

# /opt/sbin/check_gfs /prodraid01-a1/OK - I found 57 files in /prodraid01-a1/

I have about 12 GFS nodes. On every host installed Nagios NRPE daemon. To base config file of NRPE daemon (nrpe.conf) check_gfs command added in such way:

command[check_gfs]=/opt/sbin/check_gfs /prodraid01-a1/

Here is Nagios service section for GFS:

define service{      use                     clusterservice      hostgroup_name          gfsfarm      service_description     GFS availability      check_command           check_nrpe!check_gfs}
item.excerpt:encoded: During usage of GFS some of nodes getting I/O errors on GFS filesystem. A little script helps be informed about nodes with such problems check_gfs Check of GFS from command line example: # /opt/sbin/check_gfs /prodraid01-a1/ OK - I found 57 files ...

item.title: How To Compile trunk versions of numpy and scipy on OpenBSD
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
sudo pkg_add -vi atlas amd
svn co http://svn.scipy.org/svn/numpy/trunk numpy-trunk
ATLAS="/usr/local/lib/" CPPFLAGS="${CPPFLAGS} -I/usr/local/include/Atlas -I/usr/local/include/amd" python setup.py build --fcompiler=gnu
ATLAS="/usr/local/lib/" CPPFLAGS="${CPPFLAGS} -I/usr/local/include/Atlas -I/usr/local/include/amd" python setup.py install --fcompiler=gnu

svn co http://svn.scipy.org/svn/scipy/trunk scipy-trunk
ATLAS="/usr/local/lib/" CPPFLAGS="${CPPFLAGS} -I/usr/local/include/Atlas -I/usr/local/include/amd" python setup.py build --fcompiler=gnu
ATLAS="/usr/local/lib/" CPPFLAGS="${CPPFLAGS} -I/usr/local/include/Atlas -I/usr/local/include/amd" python setup.py install --fcompiler=gnu
item.excerpt:encoded: sudo pkg_add -vi atlas amd svn co http://svn.scipy.org/svn/numpy/trunk numpy-trunk ATLAS="/usr/local/lib/" CPPFLAGS="${CPPFLAGS} -I/usr/local/include/Atlas -I/usr/local/include/amd" python setup.py build --fcompiler=gnu ATLAS="/usr/local/lib/" CPP...

item.title: xrange
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
xrange([start,] stop[, step]) -> xrange object

 

    Like range(), but instead of returning a list, returns an object that

    generates the numbers in the range on demand.  For looping, this is 

    slightly faster than range() and more memory efficient.
item.excerpt:encoded: xrange([start,] stop[, step]) -> xrange object Like range(), but instead of returning a list, returns an object that generates the numbers in the range on demand. For looping, this is slightly faster than range() and more memory efficient.

item.title: Using cloc tool to calculate LOC of any git commit
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
In case you want to know you Lines Of Code counters for any git commit use awsome insructions below.

You need cloc tool to get it working right.

 

Put these lines into your ~/.gitconfig:

[difftool "cloc"] cmd = cloc --diff $LOCAL $REMOTE[alias] cloc = difftool -t cloc -y

If you already have [alias] section, append that to the end of it.

 

 

Example go taste it:

$git cloc myscript.js        1 text file.       1 text file.       0 files ignored.                             http://cloc.sourceforge.net v 1.53  T=1.0 s (1.0 files/s, 1.0 lines/s)-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Language                     files          blank        comment           code-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Javascript same                            0              0            573           3561 modified                        1              0              0             42 added                           0             15             24             61 removed                         0              0              0              3-------------------------------------------------------------------------------SUM: same                            0              0            573           3561 modified                        1              0              0             42 added                           0             15             24             61 removed                         0              0              0              3-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Or even

$git cloc d1d157650c..4a8162b       1 text file.       1 text file.       0 files ignored.                             http://cloc.sourceforge.net v 1.53  T=0.5 s (2.0 files/s, 2.0 lines/s)-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Language                     files          blank        comment           code-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Javascript same                            0              0             66            153 modified                        1              0              0              0 added                           0             15             12             80 removed                         0              0              0              0-------------------------------------------------------------------------------SUM: same                            0              0             66            153 modified                        1              0              0              0 added                           0             15             12             80 removed                         0              0              0              0-------------------------------------------------------------------------------       1 text file.       1 text file.       0 files ignored.                             http://cloc.sourceforge.net v 1.53  T=0.5 s (2.0 files/s, 2.0 lines/s)-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Language                     files          blank        comment           code-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Javascript same                            0              0            101            412 modified                        1              0              7             63 added                           0              0             24            161 removed                         0              1             11             69-------------------------------------------------------------------------------SUM: same                            0              0            101            412 modified                        1              0              7             63 added                           0              0             24            161 removed                         0              1             11             69-------------------------------------------------------------------------------       1 text file.       0 text files.       1 file ignored.
item.excerpt:encoded: In case you want to know you Lines Of Code counters for any git commit use awsome insructions below. You need cloc tool to get it working right. Put these lines into your ~/.gitconfig: [difftool "cloc"] cmd = cloc --diff $LOCAL $REMOTE [alias] clo...

item.title: How to install same packages on new ubuntu system
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
On the master machine:
dpkg --get-selections > pkg.list

On the new machine:
dpkg --set-selections
apt-get dselect-upgrade
item.excerpt:encoded: On the master machine: dpkg --get-selections > pkg.list On the new machine: dpkg --set-selections apt-get dselect-upgrade

item.title: boot from raw grub
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
linux /vmlinuz root=/dev/sda2 loop=/ubuntu/disks/root.disk ro
initrd /initrd.img
boot
item.excerpt:encoded: linux /vmlinuz root=/dev/sda2 loop=/ubuntu/disks/root.disk ro initrd /initrd.img boot

item.title: iostat for network traffic
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
This shows the amount of traffic on each network interface as well as any network errors,
dropped packets, and overruns. This also shows the name of the network interface (for example, eth0).

watch command helps to see network usage over time:
watch --interval 0.5 netstat -i inet


To identify which processes are using the network, you can use lsof.
The -i4 parameter shows which processes have IPv4 connections,
-i6 displays IPv6, -i tcp lists TCP, and -i udpdisplays applications with open UDP sockets
item.excerpt:encoded: This shows the amount of traffic on each network interface as well as any network errors, dropped packets, and overruns. This also shows the name of the network interface (for example, eth0). watch command helps to see network usage over time: wat...

item.title: Open MAN page inside the Preview.app
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded: man -t sh | open -a Preview -f
item.excerpt:encoded: man -t sh | open -a Preview -f

item.title: The /bin/sh tricky question
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
Should be interesting for a job interview for the Systems Engineer

What is the difference between two scripts:

First one:

for I in `cmd`; do
#stuff;
done"

??Second one:??

cmd | while read I; do
#stuff;
done

??
item.excerpt:encoded: Should be interesting for a job interview for the Systems Engineer What is the difference between two scripts: First one: for I in `cmd`; do #stuff; done" Second one: cmd | while read I; do #stuff; done

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: `for` case: $I will contain words (space-separated), extracted from cmd output`while` case: $I will contain lines (\n separated)Right?

item.title: Change end-of-line format for dos-mac-unix
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
To process, say, all *.txt files in the current directory:

vim *.txt:set hidden:bufdo %s/\r$//e:bufdo %s/\r/ /eg:xa
item.excerpt:encoded: To process, say, all *.txt files in the current directory: vim *.txt :set hidden :bufdo %s/\r$//e :bufdo %s/\r/ /eg :xa

item.title: [linux] How to disable CPU
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
echo 0|sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu1/online

to disable cpu1 (cpu0 would be the first one, cpu1 next and so on).

If you wanted to disable a number of them in one line, try either this (here CPUs 1 through 7):

for i in $(seq 1 7); do  echo 0|sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu$i/onlinedone

(as a one-liner this becomes: for i in $(seq 1 7); do echo 0|sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu$i/online; done) or:

echo 0|sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu{1,2,3,4,5,6,7}/online

Obviously some CPU needs to be operable, though. So I suggest you try to figure out what exactly causes the behavior when you plug in the power.

Also check out the pseudo-files offline, online, possible, present inside/sys/devices/system/cpu/ as they will give you and insight which CPUs are available at all.

Edit: given your additional information, you might want to check whether your (Ubuntu) system has the following packages installed and then edit the details into your question so we can help: apmd, toshset,acpid. Use the following (replace <package-name> with the aforementioned):

via http://askubuntu.com/questions/108887/how-to-disable-processor-drivers
item.excerpt:encoded: echo 0|sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu1/online to disable cpu1 (cpu0 would be the first one, cpu1 next and so on). If you wanted to disable a number of them in one line, try either this (here CPUs 1 through 7): for i in $(seq 1 7); do echo 0|...

item.title: VLC. How to play all your Media through AirTunes Speakers
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
AirTunes??IP: 10.0.1.1 (replace it with yours)
  
To play all your Media through AirTunes Speakers ~/Applications/VLC.app/Contents/MacOS/VLC -vv --sout='#transcode{acodec=alac}:raop{host=10.0.1.1,volume=15}' http://ice.somafm.com/dronezone

item.title: Don't be a "fixer."
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
Don't be a "fixer."

Some people just can't say no. They make themselves constantly available
to others as a means of boosting job security or feeling validated at
work. In the end, it devalues their time and leaves their to-do list
full.

http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DumbLittleMan/~3/E3CcI6qWQTU/hey-got-second-ho...

item.title: Designed in Apple California
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
The design comes from Cupertino, from people who obsess over it. Items may be manufactured in China, but they???re designed by Apple headquarters. And that matters to people. Plus, California evokes magic for many people especially the California of the mid-1970???s that gave birth to Apple Computer and really, the entire personal computer revolution. Warm weather, surfing, celebrity and a free-wheeling easy lifestyle in the age of American Graffiti are not such bad things to associate your company with.

via Jason Z.
item.excerpt:encoded: The design comes from Cupertino, from people who obsess over it. Items may be manufactured in China, but they???re designed by Apple headquarters. And that matters to people. Plus, California evokes magic for many people especially the California of...

item.title: ETL
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
ETL is for data warehousing. It's not a specific implementation to load a data warehouse, it's just a very high-level algorithm that should be used to populate a data warehouse.

  • Extract pulls data from some source.
  • Transform takes the data and manipulates it so that it can be used for..
  • Loading into your system.

ETL is that which you develop custom systems by hand to..

  • backup the truck and copy legacy systems data ( 20 different systems )
  • marry the data together from different legacy systems ( compute farm )
  • Compress the data by summarizing
  • Do some transformations
  • Load into Oracle using sql*loader Direct path you may get 1/4 billion rows loaded per hour
  • transform the data some more using pl/sql and perl or java
  • compress the data again
  • roll fact tables up by dropping columns
  • complete star schema
  • optimize your partitioned world and make fast

Be told by snobby and stupid large companies you cannot work in their ETL department because you lack direct experience with...

Ab Initio Informatica etc.

GUIs that attempt to automate what you can do manually and probably do better.

 

 

 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3392808/what-is-extract-transform-load-etl

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/51198/what-etl-tool-do-you-use/67784#67784
item.excerpt:encoded: ETL is for data warehousing. It's not a specific implementation to load a data warehouse, it's just a very high-level algorithm that should be used to populate a data warehouse. Extract pulls data from some source. Transform takes the data and man...

item.title: Use Linux swap file instead partition
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded: dd if=/dev/zero of=/swap count=32000000mkswap -v1 /swapecho "swap none swap sw" >> /etc/fstabswapon -a
item.excerpt:encoded: dd if=/dev/zero of=/swap count=32000000 mkswap -v1 /swap echo "swap none swap sw" >> /etc/fstab swapon -a

item.title: Employee Stock Option Allocations
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
"To allocate the option pool from the hiring plan, use these current ranges for option grants in Silicon Valley:

Title Range (%)

  • CEO 5 - 10
  • COO 2 - 5
  • VP 1 - 2
  • Independent Board Member 1
  • Director 0.4 - 1.25
  • Lead Engineer 0.5 - 1
  • 5+ years experience Engineer 0.33 - 0.66
  • Manager or Junior Engineer 0.2 - 0.33

    "These are rough ranges ??? not bell curves ??? for new hires once a company has raised its Series A. Option grants go down as the company gets closer to its Series B, starts making money, and otherwise reduces risk.

    "The top end of these ranges are for proven elite contributors. Most option grants are near the bottom of the ranges. Many factors affect option allocations including the quality of the existing team, the size of the opportunity, and the experience of the new hire."

    via christine.net
item.excerpt:encoded: "To allocate the option pool from the hiring plan, use these current ranges for option grants in Silicon Valley: Title Range (%) CEO 5 - 10 COO 2 - 5 VP 1 - 2 Independent Board Member 1 Director 0.4 - 1.25 Lead Engineer 0.5 - 1 5+ years experience...

item.title: Array in the /bin/sh using IFS
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
while IFS=';' read -ra ADDR; do
# process "$ADDR"
done <<< "$IN"
item.excerpt:encoded: while IFS=';' read -ra ADDR; do # process "$ADDR" done

item.title: netstat, process PID and OS X
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
How to do something like the Linux "netstat -naptu" on the Mac:

lsof -nPi
Explanation:
-i lists IP connections (both IPv4 and IPv6). -n Numbers only, for the IP addresses (prevents a lot of name resolution, which is annoying if you can't access a DNS server. -P Port numbers also only in numeric form. Else, they would be converted to service names using /etc/services.

via http://www.cosy.sbg.ac.at/~amayer/files/mac-netstat.txt
item.excerpt:encoded: How to do something like the Linux "netstat -naptu" on the Mac: lsof -nPi Explanation: -i lists IP connections (both IPv4 and IPv6). -n Numbers only, for the IP addresses (prevents a lot of name resolution, which is annoying if you can't access a ...

item.title: get hex uuid4 to shell variable
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded: UUID=$(python -c 'import uuid; print uuid.uuid4().hex')
item.excerpt:encoded: UUID=$(python -c 'import uuid; print uuid.uuid4().hex')

item.title: osx: javascript lint + vim
item.dc:creator: Anton Checkhov
item.content:encoded:
brew install jsl
jsl -help:conf > ~/jsl.conf

cat ~/.vim/ftplugin/javascript.vim
set makeprg=jsl\ -nologo\ -nofilelisting\ -nosummary\ -nocontext\ -conf\ '~/jsl.conf'\ -process\ %
set errorformat=%f(%l):\ %m
"make F10 call make for linting etc.
inoremap :make
map :make
EOF
